NewsIndia3 drown as flash floods hit many areas in Jammu
3 drown as flash floods hit many areas in Jammu
Flash floods due to cloudbursts were also reported from Qazi Mora in Poonch and high-altitude areas of Doda, Udhampur and Ramban districts. There was no report of any casualty.
By: Express News Service
Jammu | June 27, 2025 03:19 IST
2 min read
The SDRF also rescued a person from a stream in Poonch.

Three persons, including two children, died while four others were rescued as flash floods triggered by cloudbursts and heavy rains were reported from Rajouri, Poonch, Doda and Kathua districts of Jammu & Kashmir on Thursday, officials said.

Shaqafat Ali (14) and his cousin, Safeena Kousar (11), drowned due to flash floods in a rivulet in Kalakote sub-division of Rajouri. Saima (10), who was also trapped, was rescued by locals and shifted to a hospital. The children were grazing their cattle when they were swept away by the flash floods due to a cloudburst. Their bodies were retrieved.

The body of Basharat Hussain (32), a resident of Dunadi village, was fished out from a stream in Doda. He drowned while bathing in the stream on June 23.

STORY CONTINUES BELOW THIS AD

Baldev Raj (35) and Sushil Kumar (25) were rescued by the SDRF from a swollen Ujh river, near Jarmal village of Kathua.

The SDRF also rescued a person from a stream in Poonch.

Flash floods due to cloudbursts were also reported from Qazi Mora in Poonch and high-altitude areas of Doda, Udhampur and Ramban districts. There was no report of any casualty.

Heavy rains lash Saurashtra and South Gujarat districts, orange alert issued till July 2
Districts of Saurashtra and South Gujarat region, including Surat, Navsari, Valsad, Tapi, Junagadh, Gir Somnath, Porbandar, Devbhoomi Dwarka, and Morbi, received heavy rainfall on Thursday. Among the 170 talukas affected by the downpour in Gujarat, Maliya Hatina in Junagadh received the highest amount of rainfall тАУ of 135 mm тАУ till 8pm on Thursday. This [тАж]
By: Express News Service
Ahmedabad | Updated: June 27, 2025 00:53 IST
2 min read
Heavy to very heavy rainfall is expected in Banaskantha, Patan, Sabarkantha, Aravalli, Mahisagar, Navsari, Valsad, Rajkot, Junagadh and Kutch on Friday, the weather department stated.

Districts of Saurashtra and South Gujarat region, including Surat, Navsari, Valsad, Tapi, Junagadh, Gir Somnath, Porbandar, Devbhoomi Dwarka, and Morbi, received heavy rainfall on Thursday.

Among the 170 talukas affected by the downpour in Gujarat, Maliya Hatina in Junagadh received the highest amount of rainfall тАУ of 135 mm тАУ till 8pm on Thursday. This was followed by Mahuva in Surat that recorded 121 mm, Visavadar in Junagadh (118 mm), Khergam in Navsari (108 mm), Talala in Gir Somnath (102 mm), Chikhli in Navsari (102 mm), Bardoli in Surat (88 mm), Ranavav in Porbandar (82 mm), and Kalyanpur in Devbhoomi Dwarka and Kamrej in Surat (81 mm each).

Owing to a trough from northeast Arabian Sea to low-pressure area over northwest Bay of Bengal and adjoining coastal areas of Odisha and West Bengal across south Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued an orange alert for certain districts till July 2.

STORY CONTINUES BELOW THIS AD

While a yellow alert against heavy rainfall has been issued for the entire state till July 2, light thunderstorms with lightning and surface wind of 30-40 kmph accompanied with light to moderate rain is expected across Gujarat till June 30.

Heavy to very heavy rainfall is expected in Banaskantha, Patan, Sabarkantha, Aravalli, Mahisagar, Navsari, Valsad, Rajkot, Junagadh and Kutch on Friday, the weather department stated.

For Saturday, an alert against very heavy rain has been issued for Banaskantha and Patan, Jamnagar, Morbi, Dwarka and Kutch. Similar alerts have been issued for June 29 and 30 for Navsari and Valsad; July 1 for Dang, Navsari, Valsad, Tapi and Dahod, and Mahisagar and Chhota Udepur on July 2.

5 dead in Himachal flash floods
The flash floods occurred in Kangra and Kullu districts on Wednesday.
By: Express News Service
Shimla | June 27, 2025 03:13 IST
3 min read
A fire engine trapped in debris after flash floods in Kullu. (ANI)

Three bodies were recovered in Kangra on Thursday, taking the toll from flash floods triggered by cloudbursts to five, said officials.

Search operations are on to find the missing persons тАФ three each from Kullu and Kangra. Meanwhile, an unknown person died after drowning in a rivulet in Kullu on Thursday. The flash floods occurred in Kangra and Kullu districts on Wednesday.

тАЬOut of five, four were identified. As per the information provided to us by the contractor at the Hydroelectric power project, three people are still missing. Separately, a man, who had climbed up and entered a forest area to save himself yesterday from the increased water at the hydro power project site, was traced today,тАЭ said Deputy Commissioner (Kangra) Hemraj Bairwa.

STORY CONTINUES BELOW THIS AD

The three deceased have been identified as Chain Singh, a resident of Jammu & Kashmir, Aditya Thakur from Chamba, and Pardeep Verma and Chandan from Uttar Pradesh, Kangra SP Shalini Agnihotri said.

Deputy Commissioner (Kullu)Torul S Raveesh, said a search was on for three persons who had gone missing on Wednesday in Sainj valley. тАЬWe have called the teams of National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) to assist,тАЭ he said.

тАЬA man died today (Thursday) due to drowning in a rivulet which was overflowing due to incessant rain. The victim appeared to be a tourist who might have gone close to the river. Many saw him drowning. His identity is yet to be established,тАЭ Raveesh said.

Meanwhile, scores of tourists were stranded in Manikaran Valley, Banjar, Kullu and Manali due to the incessant rain and damage to roads. Officials said efforts are on to rescue them.

STORY CONTINUES BELOW THIS AD

Himachal Pradesh Chief Minister Sukhvinder Singh Sukhu said more than 15 houses collapsed and were washed away in the cloudbursts. тАЬAround nine flash floods along with three cloudbursts were reported in Kullu and Kangra in the last 24 hours. Five bodies were recovered in Kangra. Five people are still missing. I believe that roads especially connecting the villages were damaged to a large extent. We have issued necessary guidelines and warnings throughout the state,тАЭ Sukhu added.

Police in Lahaul and Spiti received information that a group of 31 trekkers, who had set out from Hamta and were scheduled to reach Chhatru, had not arrived at their destination within the expected time on Wednesday, were later located. тАЬConsidering the seriousness of the situation, a rescue team was immediately dispatched from Koksar. All 31 were safely located,тАЭ he said.

NewsCitiesChandigarhMonsoon in Panchkula: Is the city prepared or just hoping for the best?
Monsoon in Panchkula: Is the city prepared or just hoping for the best?
Shelters and helpline in place, yet many drains still choked ahead of heavy rain
Written by Nivedita
Chandigarh | June 27, 2025 00:42 IST
3 min read
A monsoon control room has been set up, with helpline number 0172-2562135 and emergency number 112 available 24x7. Calls will be routed to the relevant department or service.

Also by Amanpreet Thakur

As monsoon sets in, PanchkulaтАЩs flood preparedness is being put to the test. Of the 8,000 drains in the city, barely 50 per cent тАФ around 4,000 тАФ have been cleaned so far, according to officials. This has raised concern about the risk of waterlogging in several low-lying and vulnerable areas.

Drainage cleaning┬аstill incomplete

S K Nayyar, a city resident, said, тАЬThere are more than 8,000 drains in Panchkula, but only around 4,000 have been cleaned so far.тАЭ The work began late, he added, by which time the rain had already started. Many major drainage lines such as those measuring 5 feet, 25 feet, and 50 feet remain choked, leading to serious water accumulation.

STORY CONTINUES BELOW THIS AD

тАЬIn places like Sector 19 and Industrial Area Phase 2, water collects and has no outlet. These are low-lying and flood-prone zones,тАЭ he said. He added that Sectors 10, 9, 15, and 16 face similar issues. In Sector 15, residents often report water entering homes due to blocked drains.

He also flagged the lack of public communication. тАЬTeams should be formed, and their contact details must be made public. People need to know whom to call if waterlogging happens,тАЭ he said.

What officials are doing

Anju Rana, project officer (disaster management), said the drain cleaning work is being handled by multiple departments, including the Municipal Corporation, Irrigation, and HSVP. тАЬOnce the cleaning is done, a report is sent to the DC office,тАЭ she said.

Two to three coordination meetings have been held so far, she added. Deputy Commissioner Monika Gupta has issued instructions to departments for a timely response to any flood-like situation.

Flood-prone┬аareas identified

STORY CONTINUES BELOW THIS AD

Sector 19 and Abheypur (Wards 8 and 9) have officially been marked as flood-prone. Rana said the disaster management team has already prepared evacuation lists and has rescue teams on standby. тАЬShelters will be provided if required, with bedding, dry rations, and water bottles. If needed, boats and swimmers will be deployed for rescue,тАЭ she said.

Control room, helpline and equipment ready

A monsoon control room has been set up, with helpline number 0172-2562135 and emergency number 112 available 24├Ч7. Calls will be routed to the relevant department or service.

тАЬBoats, life jackets, and rescue materials have been arranged,тАЭ Rana said. Teams from the Army, NDRF, and Red Cross are in coordination and on alert. Volunteers and sarpanches in rural areas have also been informed and trained.

Gaps remain

Despite these preparations, several gaps persist. Nayyar said emergency response teams have not yet been publicly named, and many key drains remain blocked. He also noted that a drainage channel in Sector 19 had been sold off and replaced with housing, leaving the area without any drainage outlet.

Final word

STORY CONTINUES BELOW THIS AD

тАЬIt all depends on how serious the situation gets,тАЭ said Rana. тАЬThe disaster management team is ready, and our response will be scaled up as per the need.тАЭ

But Nayyar insisted that better planning, quicker action, and transparent communication are crucial. тАЬPanchkula has taken steps, but with the rain already here, every delay counts.тАЭ
